text: in our research we had two main aims
which was to look at look at how much
patients actually are doing in a typical
oncology unit kind of like Bedford
hospital and secondly to find out
whether patients had any concerns or
barriers that were limiting the exercise
levels of any we used a validated
screening tool for exercise known as the
general practice physical activity
questionnaire which is a very useful
tool for kind of objectively giving a
categorized and how much exercise
patients are actually doing and what we
found was that only eleven percent of
the patients in our cohort were
achieving active levels that means that
eighty-nine percent were were
insufficiently active and should be
advised to do more exercise another
aspect data rows more findings was that
patients are actually more aware that
exercise is good for them so the message
has gotten out there I think what we
need to do is to now adapt information
materials so that they don't focus just
on relaying the message that exercise is
good for you but also to kind of
understand why patients are still not
doing enough exercise even though they
know this and what we found is that a
lot of patients are concerned about
doing more exercise because for
health-related reasons so because you
know cancer patients they deal with a
lot of stresses related to their
diagnosis and the treatment so they
often feel that they're too tired to do
exercise there in too much pain to do
exercise a lot of patients also feel
that they can't schedule exercise into
their busy timetables and there is still
a subset of patients who are who are
where that exercise good for them but
are still still not sure still don't
realize how much exercise that really
requires so 25 percent of the patients
at our cohort thought they were ready

twenty-five percent of these specific
patients were actually active on the GP
paq so I think what we need to do is
adapt information materials so that we

where they can be supervised by trained

professionals can kind of on Taylor

down with patients go through all the
concerns
exercise was the main factor we did
collect some data on smoking and obesity
so sixty-eight percent of our patient
cohort were overweight or obese which is
obviously also a risk factor for
cardiovascular disease and increases the
rate of side effects as well so that's
another aspect that would be helped with
doing more exercise and we did look
briefly it's smoking levels so only
seven percent of the cohort are
currently smoking 52-percent we're

there's a trend towards succeeding in
